question: Question_01_(c)
statement:
\emph{Determine whether the following statement is true or false. If it
is true, provide justification. If it is false, provide a
counterexample.}

\textbf{(c)} If $f$ has a local minimum at 1, then $f$'(1) = 0.
sols:
The statement is \textbf{false}.

A minimum always occurs at a critical point - however, there are two
possible reasons for a critical point: either $\displaystyle f'(x) = 0$
\textbf{or} $\displaystyle f'(x)$ does not exist. In this second case,
the derivative is not equal to zero, but there can still be a local
minimum. For example, the derivative does not exist if there is a cusp
(sharp corner), a vertical tangent or the function is discontinuous; an
example of a cusp is given below:

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{MER_Math_110_April_2013_1c_solution.png}
\caption{MER Math 110 April 2013 1c solution.png}
\end{figure}

In this case there is a minimum at \emph{x = 1} but
$\displaystyle f'(x)$ does not exist, so it can't be equal to zero. So
we found a counter example and hence the statement is \textbf{false}.
hints:
Recall the definition of a critical point. Is there more than just the
criteria that its derivative is zero?
